courseDescription: This course provides an introduction to the multidisciplinary field of public health. Students will learn the history, core functions, and roles of the US public health system through grounding in the 12 foundational public health knowledge areas.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge in foundational public health areas
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate public health concepts

courseTitle: Introduction to Biostatistics for Public Health
courseDescription: This course introduces fundamental concepts in biostatistics. Students will learn how to analyze and interpret numeric data using statistical tools to investigate and evaluate public health issues.

This course provides an introduction to 21st century environmental health science and practice. In addition to covering foundational environmental issues affecting people’s health, the class familiarizes students with contemporary environmental health challenges such as climate change, sea level rise, antibiotic resistance, food and sustainability, plastics and environmental health, disaster preparedness, lead poisoning, radiation safety and health, environmental justice, cultural competence, and environmental risk communication.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge about environmental health impacts of plastics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the effects of climate change
Assessing health risks associated with environmental factors
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and interpreting data on environmental health issues
Leading initiatives on environmental health and justice

courseDescription: This introductory readings course provides students with an overview of the public health sector from a local, national, and global perspective.  The history of public health and recent events leading to a complete transformation of service delivery are two of the topics presented.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding modern public health delivery systems
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interpreting and communicating public health data
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Assessing the effectiveness of public health interventions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and implementing public health initiatives

courseTitle: Social and Behavioral Sciences for Public Health
courseDescription: This course reviews and critiques psychological, social, and cultural concepts and models relevant to health and disease in society. Students will learn how to select and apply appropriate social and behavioral models to the design of public health interventions and policies. Existing social inequalities in health status related to race, social class, and gender will be explored, as will the intersection between risk factors and the development/implementation of public health interventions.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Critiquing social, cultural, and psychological concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of health and disease concepts
Understanding intersection of risk factors and public health interventions
Selection of appropriate social and behavioral models
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Addressing health disparities related to race, social class, and gender

courseDescription: This course will introduce the principles and basic methods of epidemiology for applications in public health. These include measures of disease frequency and association, study design, sources of errors in epidemiological studies, validity and reliability of diagnostic and screening tests, causation, and outbreak investigations.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of diagnostic and screening tests
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying sources of errors in epidemiological studies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Ensuring validity and reliability in studies

courseDescription: Public health professionals require skills to identify problems that face population groups, and to delineate ways to solve them. Often this necessitates conducting small- or large-scale investigations on their own, or as a member of a project team. The goal of this course is to provide practical, step-by-step guidance to the research process in public health.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborative team work in research projects

courseDescription: In this course, students will review the structure and functions of American and international healthcare systems, public health practice, and managerial responsibilities. Additionally, this course will introduce students to the practice of systems thinking in public health and the influence of systems thinking on public health policy.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of American and international healthcare systems
Practicing systems thinking in public health
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication in a healthcare setting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Solving problems in a public health context
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Implementing systems thinking for organizational improvement

courseTitle: Environmental Health Law, Justice and Governance
courseDescription: This course surveys the basic legal concepts affecting environmental health services and program enforcement & administration. It is designed to provide a fundamental background of environmental and public health law for public health officers and other environmental health workers to fulfill their respective roles more successfully.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with public health officers and other environmental health workers
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in environmental health law enforcement

courseTitle: Health Communication and Social Marketing for Public Health
courseDescription: This course examines social marketing concepts and tools for influencing health behavior change. Students learn how to design, implement, and evaluate strategies for social marketing campaigns.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Strategic planning for health behavior change
Analyzing effectiveness of health marketing strategies

courseTitle: Environmental and Occupational Health Risk Assessment
courseDescription: This course is an introduction to risk assessment, as applied to environmental and workplace hazards.  It examines the fundamental concepts of risk.  Students will learn the United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) standard and advanced methodology for quantitative risk assessment including hazard identification, exposure assessment, dose-response modeling, risk characterization, and risk communication.  Utilization of qualitative assessment methods and ecological risk assessment are also explored.
Technical and Digital Skills: USEPA standard and advanced methodology for quantitative risk assessment
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Application of USEPA methodology for risk assessment
Implementation of qualitative and quantitative risk assessment methods

courseDescription: Students will examine financial evaluation of the health care industry, the source of funds, and the effects of changing patient policies. Other topics of interest will be financial strategies, budgets and capital outlay. Cross-listed with CHP 633.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Assessing financial impact of policy changes

courseDescription: This course provides an introduction to the topic of global health disparities through an in-depth examination and discussion of the relationship between social injustice and inequitable health outcomes. Students will be introduced to the behavioral, social and environmental determinants of health disparities and the pathways and mechanisms leading to inequitable health outcomes in vulnerable groups, as well as strategies for addressing these determinants to improve health.
Technical and Digital Skills: Research on social and environmental determinants of health
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective discussion and debate on social issues
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluation of methods for addressing health disparities
Understanding of behavioral determinants of health

courseDescription: This course is an introduction to the basic principles of toxicology, and the interactions between toxic agents and living systems.  The course consists of a study of general principles, dose response, toxin recognition and evaluation, chemicals, the human environment, and ecological toxicology.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge in toxin recognition and evaluation
Familiarity with chemicals and their interactions with living systems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of effects of toxins on human environment

courseDescription: This course provides public health promotion graduate students with a comprehensive overview of the practical and theoretical principles and skills needed to plan, implement, and evaluate health promotion programs in a variety of settings. The course will help students apply constructs from theories to understand the determinants of health behaviors and emphasizes the importance of addressing health behavior change at the individual, interpersonal, organizational, community and societal levels of the social ecological model.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Addressing health behavior change at different societal levels

courseDescription: This course examines the availability, use of interpretation of data obtained from traditional and new data systems used for population health monitoring. Included are public health surveillance systems, vital statistics, hospital discharge data, Health Plan Employer Data and Set (HEDIS), immunization information, school health data, 1996 Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA), and regulatory agency data related to health.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of public health surveillance systems
Use of hospital discharge data system
Use of Health Plan Employer Data and Set (HEDIS)
Understanding of 1996 Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA)
Use and interpretation of regulatory agency data related to health
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating data from various health systems
Identifying trends and patterns in health data
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing and organizing various data systems

courseDescription: This course provides public and community health graduate students with a comprehensive overview of the practical and theoretical principles and skills needed to plan, implement, and evaluate health programs in a variety of settings.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in public and community health settings

courseDescription: In this course, students build on their earlier practice activities (i.e., Practice Labs) and undertake an extensive, hands-on activity at a field-based practice site. The Practice Labs, which are completed prior to taking this course, are designed to meet foundational and track competencies as well as prepare students for an on-site work experience.

courseTitle: Cultural Issues in Health Promotion and Education
courseDescription: This course provides an introduction for multicultural communication for health promotion and disease management. Topics to be covered include how to work collaboratively in diverse groups with an understanding of health behaviors, values, and health benefits.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding of health behaviors and values
Analyzing health benefits in a multicultural context
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading diverse teams in health promotion

courseDescription: This course enables the student to develop systematic and analytical frameworks for understanding health and healthcare policy issues. It will introduce the policy process, background research necessary for policy implementation, and implementation strategies.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Development of systematic frameworks for policy issues
Analytical understanding of health and healthcare policy issues

courseDescription: An examination of the political, social, cultural, and ethical issues for disease prevention and health promotion in developing countries. Students will learn to identify international health prerogatives aimed at improving health status through education and intervention.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of health status in developing countries
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in disease prevention and health promotion

courseDescription: This course examines the legal requirements affecting the health care industry, including a survey of the basic concepts and content in the major areas of health law, an explanation and identification of sources of legal authority, and a familiarity with legal language.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interpretation and explanation of legal concepts
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Application of legal requirements in health care settings
Leadership in legal aspects of health care

courseTitle: Grant Writing for Public Health Practice
courseDescription: This course covers issues and problems concerned with the development of grants and contracts as they relate to the health professions.  The course focuses on the multiple roles of funding agencies and the importance of matching the interests of the grant seeker with the corresponding funding agency.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Interest alignment between grant seeker and funding agency
Identification and resolution of grant development issues

courseDescription: This is the culminating course for the MPH program. Students demonstrate an ability to integrate and synthesize foundational and concentration-specific competencies from their MPH program coursework. Students complete assignments that address timely public health issues culminating in high quality written products and an e-portfolio that demonstrate the analysis, synthesis and intersection of course work and concurrent practicum experiences. Students from all tracks are required to complete this course prior to graduation.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Synthesis of foundational and concentration-specific competencies
Interpretation and evaluation of practicum experiences

courseDescription: This course presents modern methods for analyzing data from epidemiologic and public health studies using the latest statistical methods. Emphasis is placed on practical, applied theories/concepts, aspects of methods for the analysis of diverse types of data including from observational studies, and the use of a computer for quantitative data management. Emphasis will also be placed on technical and statistical report writing.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communication of technical and statistical reports
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing data from epidemiologic and public health studies
Analysis of diverse types of data

courseDescription: This course covers programming and computing techniques using contemporary statistical packages. Emphasis is placed on practical issues relating to organizing, modifying, and preparing data for analysis.

The course aims to prepare graduate students with hands-on experience in producing common epidemiological measures while critically evaluating the quality of data and the design of epidemiological investigations.
This course focuses on the epidemiology of infectious diseases from a public health perspective. It applies traditional and contemporary epidemiological methods used to deal with infectious diseases.
Technical and Digital Skills: Ability to apply traditional and contemporary epidemiological methods
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of epidemiological methods to real-world infectious diseases

courseDescription: This course introduces students to the political, social, cultural, environmental, and ethical issues globally involved in disease prevention and health promotion. Specific emphasis is on incidence/prevalence, morbidity/mortality, and identified health problems in specific regions and countries.  This course also identifies global health prerogatives aimed at improving health status through education and intervention.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communication of health issues and solutions
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of health issues in specific regions and countries
Identification and evaluation of health problems
Development of interventions for health improvement
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in health education and intervention

courseDescription: The goal of this course is to guide students with a public health perspective to develop skills to identify and analyze environmental health problems globally. It is designed to provide knowledge on recognizing and evaluating major environmental health issues and risk factors in developed and developing countries by using group discussions and real-life case studies.
Technical and Digital Skills: Evaluation of major environmental health issues and risk factors

courseDescription: This second-year MPH course examines the interrelationships between individual and societal decisions and the global environment, and the consequences these interrelationships have for public health. Students engage in an in-depth examination of key environmental health issues, analyze the public health implications, and consider various strategies for improving individual and population health, and enhancing sustainability, in the local area, the region, the nation and around the world.
Technical and Digital Skills: In-depth examination of environmental health issues
Understanding of strategies for improving individual and population health
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and debate on societal decisions impacting the environment
Presentation of strategies for enhancing sustainability
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of the interrelationships between individual and societal decisions and the global environment
Critical evaluation of environmental health issues
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and prioritizing environmental health issues
